author: By Laurel Graeber
title: The Wide World of Puppetry Converges on New York
description: This year’s International Puppet Fringe Festival surveys puppetry traditions from around the globe, and celebrates the legacy of the master puppeteer Ralph Lee.
content: Forget the sunglasses, the baseball caps, the featherweight clothing. Heat or no heat, it’s time to choose a fantastical mask and a wild costume and head to the Lower East Side to join a Wednesday evening parade. Hades himself will welcome you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Judson Jones
title: Storms Sweep Across Eastern U.S., Killing 2
description: The weather system barreled through a stretch from Georgia to New York, disrupting travel, downing trees and power lines and leaving more than a million homes and businesses without power.
content: A “complicated and active” storm system swept across the Eastern United States on Monday evening, delivering widespread thunderstorms that killed at least two people, grounded thousands of flights and left more than a million homes and businesses without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Climate Is Now a Culture War Issue
description: And it couldn’t have happened at a worse time.
content: Understanding climate denial used to seem easy: It was all about greed. Delve into the background of a researcher challenging the scientific consensus, a think tank trying to block climate action or a politician pronouncing climate change a hoax and you would almost always find major financial backing from the fossil fuel industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Elite Chinese Generals Ousted
description: Also, South Korea relocates an international scout convention as a typhoon looms.
content: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the once-corrupt military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel — the People’s Liberation Army Rocket Force, which manages conventional and nuclear missiles — is under a shadow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Former Officer Gets More Than 4 Years in Final Sentencing for Police Killing of George Floyd
description: Tou Thao, who worked for the Minneapolis Police Department, held back bystanders as other officers restrained Mr. Floyd in a way that led to his death.
content: A judge in Minneapolis has sentenced Tou Thao, a former police officer who held back bystanders as other officers restrained George Floyd, to four years and nine months in state prison. In May, Mr. Thao was found guilty of aiding and abetting second-degree manslaughter in Mr. Floyd’s killing. This is the final sentencing in the killing of Mr. Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Fed Official Wonders: ‘Do We Need to Do Another Rate Increase?’
description: The head of the powerful New York Fed said that it was an “open question,” and that rates could fall next year.
content: John C. Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, thinks that the central bank’s push to cool the economy is near its peak and that he expects that interest rates could begin to come down next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Why a Trans Republican Keeps Engaging With Conservatives
description: There aren’t many trans elected officials — especially Republicans. Jane Coaston interviews Jennifer Williams about what’s happening to the G.O.P.
content: Jennifer Williams is a member of the City Council in Trenton, N.J. She’s a Republican from a military family and says she’s far more along the lines of Teddy Roosevelt or Dwight Eisenhower than Donald Trump. She is focused on solving Trenton’s problems — from stemming the tide of violent crime to helping veterans get access to mental health care in one of the poorest cities in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Can One Artist Do Everything?
description: Out of curiosity — or necessity — more creative people are trying their hand at multiple genres.
content: Not so long ago, an artist picked one medium and stuck to it. Actors were actors; painters were painters; and singers were singers (usually. They were then, as now, the rebels of the bunch). There were exceptions to this, of course, but they tended to be regarded with either awe or faint derision: To dare to be proficient in two genres could feel not so much ambitious as uncommitted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Sarah Eckinger
title: Ukraine Replaces Soviet Emblem on Kyiv’s Motherland Monument
description: The Motherland Monument — a 335-foot-tall stainless steel behemoth towering over Ukraine’s capital — was unveiled in 1981 and designed to assert Soviet invincibility.
content: Ukraine has replaced the Soviet emblem on one of Kyiv’s most prominent monuments with its own coat of arms, part of a broader push since the full-scale invasion to stamp out tributes to Russian power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville
title: Saudi Aramco Reports $30 Billion in Profit for Latest Quarter
description: It was a steep fall from last year’s record profit, but still enough for the company to introduce additional dividend payments and increase capital investment.
content: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest energy company, on Monday reported a nearly 40 percent drop in profit for the second quarter, compared with a year ago, when high oil prices produced record earnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Rhoda Karpatkin, Who Led Consumer Reports for Decades, Dies at 93
description: The first woman to be named executive director of Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, she expanded its readership and its influence in Washington.
content: Rhoda Karpatkin, who pressed for painstaking product testing for safety and quality while promoting comparison shopping for value during more than four decades at Consumers Union as counsel, executive director and president, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: England Through to Quarterfinals Despite Red Card for Lauren James
description: Lauren James was sent off in the second half of England’s penalty shootout victory over Nigeria, which could prompt a suspension from FIFA.
content: England is through to the quarterfinals of the World Cup and that will be all that matters for now. Four of its penalty kicks went in and two of Nigeria’s did not, and on a night when not much went according to plan, that was enough. The other questions — important questions — can wait for a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: These Clever Fish Have Mastered the Fake Out
description: Trumpetfish use a number of tricks to catch prey, but research shows that one of their most effective tactics has much in common with human hunters’ subterfuge.
content: Trumpetfish like to snack on damselfish and shrimp in coral reefs and sea grass beds around the world. But with 20-inch long bodies and conspicuously large snouts, they need tricks to sneak up on their prey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Jin Yu Young
title: 3 Die as Firefighting Helicopter Crashes in Southern California
description: The aircraft carrying the three men collided with another over Riverside County, east of Los Angeles, an official said. The other helicopter landed safely.
content: Three people were killed when a helicopter that was deployed to fight a wildfire in Southern California collided with another and crashed on Sunday evening, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainslie Hogarth
title: So Your Mother Is Hiding in the Multiverse? Then Here, Eat This.
description: In Lauren Beukes’s surreal new book, “Bridge,” a young woman embarks on a metaphysical quest to find her family before a fearsome hunter does.
content: Bridge, the titular character in Lauren Beukes’s trippy new novel, is adrift. She has dropped out of a business-degree program, now works full time at a bookstore, and is kicking herself for not pursuing film like she really wanted. Or only maybe wanted. Bridge doesn’t actually know what she wants or who she is. She’s the opposite of her boundlessly supportive best friend Dom, a nonbinary Puerto Rican artist who’s worked very hard to know exactly who they are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Aspen for Cheapskates
description: The Colorado town associated with glitzy ski trips also draws summer visitors who love hiking, biking and cultural festivals. Here’s how to craft an affordable vacation in this famously expensive enclave.
content: Over an $8.50 pint of craft beer from Aspen Brewing Company, which is comparable to what I pay at home in Chicago, I realized that Aspen, Colo., is not expensive by big-city standards. It’s expensive by small-town standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: A New Role for Kamala Harris in the 2024 Campaign, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Xi Rebuilt the Military to His Liking. Now a Shake-Up Threatens Its Image.
description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
content: As Xi Jinping has entrenched his hold on power in China, he has likened himself to a physician, eradicating the toxins of corruption and disloyalty that threaten the rule of the Communist Party. And his signature project for over a decade has been bringing to heel the once extravagantly corrupt military leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Mostly Mozart’s Repertoire Broadens With Its Audience
description: At recent Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra performances, visibly diverse crowds took in programming new to the ensemble.
content: For the past 10 months, the back side of David Geffen Hall has greeted passers-by with Nina Chanel Abney’s installation “San Juan Heal.” Its bold, color-blocked illustrations pay tribute to the largely Black and Puerto Rican neighborhood that was torn down to make way for Lincoln Center in the mid-20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller, Luis Alberto Rodriguez and Carlos Nazario
title: For Dua Lipa, Just Being a Pop Star Isn’t Enough
description: Though the singer has maintained a strict line between her music and her private life, she’s leveraging her personal passions in a bid to become a media mogul.
content: LET’S GET THIS out of the way: Dua Lipa is finishing her third album. It’s due for release in 2024 and, despite the trend of musicians announcing and delaying records for years, Lipa will almost certainly meet her deadline. It’s funny to think of a pop star — or any successful young artist — as just another striving professional. But at 27, Lipa has already become the kind of multihyphenate entrepreneur who not only finishes her assignments on time but discusses strategy and efficiency with the clarity of a company founder delivering a TED Talk. “If I wasn’t as organized as I am, I would be a mess right now,” she says when we meet one drizzly May afternoon in London. The singer had asked one of her favorite restaurants, Sushi on Jones, hidden on the second floor of a King’s Cross concert venue, to open before dinner so we could have the place to ourselves, then arrived 10 minutes early to make sure everything was as planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Lowry
title: Imagine What Another Indictment Could Do for Donald Trump
description: Mr. Trump is unlikely to be taken down by the very authorities he says are corrupt and arrayed against him.
content: Donald Trump is the most-indicted front-running presidential candidate ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Australia looks to live up to expectations.
description: Is Monday the day we see the return of Sam Kerr? That is the question. So far in this tournament, the co-host country Australia has been without its top star — and has barely held on, advancing with a big victory in a must-win group stage match over Canada. Kerr suggested she was game-ready on Sunday, telling reporters: “I’m really excited. I will play.” After New Zealand exited the World Cup in the group stage, Australia has to win to keep at least one host country in contention.
content: Is Monday the day we see the return of Sam Kerr? That is the question. So far in this tournament, the co-host country Australia has been without its top star — and has barely held on, advancing with a big victory in a must-win group stage match over Canada. Kerr suggested she was game-ready on Sunday, telling reporters: “I’m really excited. I will play.” After New Zealand exited the World Cup in the group stage, Australia has to win to keep at least one host country in contention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘Toros’ Review: Why Are We Still Friends?
description: Old relationships bend, then break, in Danny Tejera’s finely detailed character study of languishing jet-set twentysomethings.
content: We all know this guy, or a version of him, anyway: smug, entitled, yet always somehow kept around. He cares only about his interests, his opinions on them, and does not welcome interruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: aptitude
description: This word has appeared in 40 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word aptitude has appeared in 40 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “A Trailblazing Black Cartoonist’s Work: ‘It’s Unapologetic, and It’s the Truth’” by Robert Ito:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Killing of Native American Man Stirs Anger at Border Patrol
description: Raymond Mattia was shot nine times by agents late one night outside his home on tribal lands in Arizona.
content: It was pitch black when the Border Patrol rolled up to Raymond Mattia’s home on a remote corner of the Tohono O’odham reservation in southern Arizona, investigating a report of gunshots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Why You Like the Sound of ‘Barbenheimer’
description: What makes a good portmanteau?
content: Most of us have become acquainted, whether by choice or against our will, with the “Barbenheimer” phenomenon, a blended cinematic experience that consists of taking in both Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie” and Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” on the same day (the order matters a little).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Moves First Group of Asylum Seekers Onto Barge
description: A small group of migrants was transferred to the Bibby Stockholm, a divisive symbol of the Conservative government’s immigration stance.
content: Thousands of migrants travel to Britain every year on small boats, risking their lives to cross the English Channel and hoping to claim asylum when they reach dry land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Ukraine Says Russian Missiles Struck Town of Pokrovsk, Killing 5
description: The strikes hit the center of the small city in eastern Ukraine twice within 40 minutes, officials said. At least 31 people were injured.
content: Russian forces shelled a small city in eastern Ukraine twice in quick succession on Monday evening, killing at least five people, including an emergency worker who was responding to the first attack, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Some Urban Oases Are Closed to the Public
description: In New York, many privately owned public spaces are out of compliance with the agreements developers made to maintain them and keep them open.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at little public spaces around the city that add up to a big bonus for developers — and how some of them are not being used the way the developers promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Murray and Kate Shaw
title: One of the Most Brazen Republican Schemes Around Abortion Is Happening in Ohio
description: Supporters of reproductive freedom across the country must continue to flock to the polls.
content: An unusual special election that lawmakers have scheduled in Ohio for Tuesday may tell us a great deal about this moment in American politics after Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The New York Fed President Sees Interest Rates Coming Down With Inflation
description: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, John C. Williams pondered the economy’s future. This is the full transcript.
content: On Aug. 2, 2023, John C. Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, spoke with The New York Times. Below is a full transcript of his remarks during the 50-minute interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Paige Cowett, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Brad Fisher and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Economy is on an Upswing. Should Biden Get Credit for It?
description: The United States looks set to avoid a long-feared recession, but many Americans are not yet chalking it up to the president.
content: The latest economic figures are some of the best of President Biden’s tenure so far. It appears increasingly likely that the United States has managed to tame high inflation without causing a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: A Twitch Streamer’s Giveaway Caused Mayhem in New York
description: Kai Cenat has been charged with inciting a riot, among other charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: A Quaint French Bookstore, a Vicious Dog and a Dead Toy Poodle
description: An Upper East Side bookstore was known for its children’s books and for Syko the German shepherd, who often attacked other pets.
content: The quaint little shop on the Upper East Side is New York City’s only store dedicated to French children’s books. But lately, the shop, La Librairie des Enfants, has earned a more sinister distinction: It has been the sometime home of Syko, a 98-pound white German shepherd with a penchant for eviscerating smaller dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Gaza Protests Struggle to Gain Traction as Police Crack Down
description: Demonstrators’ efforts to rally against Hamas, including at protests on Monday, have been foiled by a heavy security presence.
content: Security forces in the Gaza Strip prevented protesters from holding rallies across the territory on Monday, quelling a rare expression of dissent against Hamas, the authoritarian Islamist group that controls the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Greatest Show in Nashville Is Happening in the Sky
description: Too often, conflicts with wildlife end in the death of inconvenient animals that are only trying to live their lives.
content: When you don’t know what’s coming, the whole glorious spectacle of it can catch you off guard. There you are on a downtown Nashville sidewalk, gawking at the tourists on the transportainment vehicles or just listening to the music pouring from the open-doored bars, when it begins to dawn on you that the sky is full of birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 31, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: There Might Be Less Plastic in the Sea Than We Thought. But Read On.
description: A new study might sound like good news, but there’s a problem: Ocean pollution appears to be growing fast.
content: There’s less plastic pollution flowing into the ocean from land than scientists previously thought, according to a study published Monday in the journal Nature Geoscience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Tiny Gap Reveals a Yawning One for the U.S. Women’s Team
description: The idea that the United States was eliminated from the Women’s World Cup by a millimeter is an illusion. Denying that will only guarantee more failures.
content: Even in the highest-resolution image, examined up close, there was not so much as a discernible sliver of daylight. The margin by which the United States was eliminated from the Women’s World Cup was so microscopic that it cannot be expressed in a unit of measurement the country fully recognizes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: How Long Will Interest Rates Stay High?
description: It’s pricey to borrow to buy a business, car or home these days. Interest rates are expected to fall in coming years — how much is up for debate.
content: Dr. Alice Mills was thinking of selling her veterinary practice in Lexington, Ky., this year, but she decided to put the move off because she worried that it would be difficult to sell in an era of rising interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Lifted by Lea Michele, ‘Funny Girl’ Recoups on Broadway
description: The show, which opened in the spring of 2022, has had a remarkable box office turnaround after Michele replaced its original star.
content: The Broadway revival of “Funny Girl” starring Lea Michele is now officially a hit: It has recouped its capitalization costs, completing a remarkable box office turnaround of the sort rarely seen in the commercial theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: After a Long and Painful Absence, Writing Her Way Home Again
description: After early success with her first book, Mona Susan Power sank into years of depression. A new one, “A Council of Dolls,” offered her a chance to heal.
content: When she was 4 years old she met Martin Luther King Jr., who tugged playfully on her pigtails; at 17 she found herself at the Academy Awards, mingling with a bedazzlement of movie stars. By her early 30s she had earned a law degree from Harvard, an M.F.A. from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and a PEN/Hemingway Award for her lauded debut novel, “The Grass Dancer.” Then Mona Susan Power’s world went dark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Nine Provocative William Friedkin Movies to Stream
description: The director specialized in grimy thrillers and social dramas that occasionally courted controversy.
content: An iconoclast even among his New Hollywood peers coming up in the 1970s, the director William Friedkin built a reputation for grimy, high-impact thrillers and social dramas that sought to get a rise out of audiences and frequently drew the controversy they courted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde McGrady
title: Is Social Justice for the Birds? Audubon Attempts an Answer.
description: A battle over the group namesake’s ties to slavery grew into a conflict over diversity, highlighting complications that have arisen in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death.
content: On the same day George Floyd was murdered by a police officer on a Minneapolis street — Memorial Day, 2020 —  Christian Cooper was searching for songbirds in Central Park. Mr. Cooper, who is Black, would be vaulted to fame after a run-in with a white woman who called the police and falsely claimed he was threatening her when he asked her to leash her dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Nate Schweber
title: Queens Doctor Charged With Drugging and Assaulting Patients on Camera
description: Zhi Alan Cheng, a former doctor at a prominent New York hospital, recorded dozens of videos as he raped and sexually abused women, prosecutors said.
content: The grim accusation rocked a major New York City hospital late last year: An emerging gastroenterologist had been charged with first-degree rape. Prosecutors said he had drugged a girlfriend and filmed the assault at his apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 5, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about Meta’s restriction of news content in Canada misstated the month the online news law will take effect. It is December, not January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: Ex-F.B.I. Official in Talks to Resolve Charges of Working for Oligarch
description: Once the F.B.I.’s top counterintelligence official in New York City, Charles F. McGonigal was charged with concealing contacts with foreign nationals.
content: A former senior F.B.I. official is in talks to resolve criminal charges in two separate indictments, including entering a possible guilty plea as early as next week in a case involving accusations that he worked for a Russian oligarch, according to a public filing and statements by his lawyer in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: G.O.P. Contenders Feed Voter Distrust in Courts, Schools and Military
description: As Donald J. Trump has escalated his attacks on the justice system and other core institutions, his competitors for the Republican nomination have followed his lead.
content: Ron DeSantis says the military is more interested in global warming and “gender ideology” initiatives than in national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: William Friedkin’s Final Film to Premiere at the Venice Film Festival
description: “The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,” with Jake Lacy and Kiefer Sutherland, was the director’s first new drama in more than a decade.
content: The director William Friedkin died on Monday at age 87, leaving behind a filmography that included hits like “The Exorcist” and “The French Connection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: 5 Wellness Trends to Watch
description: A look back at pills, products and practices that popped up in the first half of this year.
content: The internet metabolizes wellness trends the way it churns through celebrity divorce announcements or song snippets on TikTok. Health hacks like slurping down olive oil or chugging bone broth burble up, break through, then slink into obscurity. All these frenetic fads make the concept of “wellness” squishy — wait, we’re drinking lettuce water? When did everyone get so concerned about their cortisol?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Six Ways to Experience Athens Like a Local
description: Enjoy the Greek capital’s glorious past and buzzing modern life while also avoiding the worst of the tourist bottlenecks and the steamy weather.
content: Henry Miller once wrote, “The light of Greece opened my eyes, penetrated my pores, expanded my whole being.” Greece can be enlightening — and nowhere more so than its capital city, Athens. But it’s also true that, in the summer, it can feel burning hot, with an average temperature of 84 degrees Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Flights are grounded at airports across the Eastern U.S. because of severe weather.
description: The groundings caused a ripple effect of delays across the country.
content: Airports across the Eastern United States grounded numerous flights because of the threat of severe weather on Monday afternoon, leading to thousands of flight delays and cancellations that extended into the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Fights to Stay Competitive in a One-Sided G.O.P. Primary
description: The former South Carolina governor is campaigning at a grueling pace, but polling suggests that so far, Republican voters aren’t flocking to her.
content: Nikki Haley is campaigning at a grueling pace as she fights to stay competitive in the Republican presidential contest, crisscrossing Iowa and New Hampshire to find a clear lane forward in a race dominated by Donald J. Trump and his mountain of legal problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In the Trump Era, Is Iowa’s Fabled Caucus Beside the Point?
description: Every four years, politicians flock to Iowa to prove their mettle. It’s different in the Trump era.
content: Did you hear? There was a mass gathering of Republican 2024 hopefuls in Iowa on Sunday — near Cedar Rapids, amid the midsummer seas of ripening cornstalks and the darker hues of rows of soybeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Republican Party’s Split on Economics
description: Why an argument over economic policy is roiling the party.
content: The Wall Street Journal’s editorial board has spent the last few months trying to boost Gov. Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign. It has called his legislative record “as impressive as you’ll find,” while touting Florida’s population growth and noting that the state’s age-adjusted Covid death rate is well below the national average. As DeSantis’s campaign has sagged, The Journal’s editorialists have offered him tactical advice for confronting Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris, Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Paramount Agrees to Sell Simon & Schuster to KKR, a Private Equity Firm
description: The deal, for $1.62 billion, will put control of a cultural touchstone in the hands of a financial buyer.
content: Paramount said on Monday it had reached a deal to sell Simon & Schuster, one of the biggest and most prestigious publishing houses in the United States, to the private-equity firm KKR, in a major changing of the guard in the books business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Christopher Petkanas
title: Judge Weighs Conservatorship for the Former Supreme Cindy Birdsong
description: The singer’s family has asked the court to approve a legal arrangement that would govern her medical decisions and finances after relatives objected to the previous care by a longtime friend.
content: A judge in Los Angeles is set to consider on Tuesday whether to establish a conservatorship for an 83-year-old former member of the Supremes, whose family has argued that her physical and mental frailties have made her vulnerable to undue influence for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New York City Has ‘Tepid’ Plans for Fixing Rikers, Monitor Says
description: City officials are not moving quickly to fix the troubled jail complex despite the growing prospect of losing authority over it, according to a new report.
content: If New York City officials feel any urgency about fixing the persistent problems at the Rikers Island jail complex, they are not showing it, according to a report filed on Monday by the federal official appointed to monitor the lockup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Outlander’ and ‘Hard Knocks’
description: The Starz series comes back for a sixth season and the HBO documentary series on NFL training camp follows the New York Jets.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 7-13. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Recovery Left Nevada Behind. Can the State Change Its Luck?
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 7, 2023.
content: “Movie stars and thousands of dollars in tips. If it was up to me, I was never going to leave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea Tells Scouts to Leave World Jamboree Site as Typhoon Nears
description: The main campsite for the troubled gathering will be packed up and thousands of scouts will disperse across the country until the event ends on Saturday.
content: After several setbacks at the World Scout Jamboree, the South Korea-hosted event faces yet another hurdle: As Typhoon Khanun makes its way to the nation’s coast this week, the participants will be leaving the campsite early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: After a Flood, Saving Appalachia’s History Piece by Piece
description: Appalshop, a cultural center in Kentucky, has recovered more than 13,500 items after a devastating flood a year ago. Many are being restored and digitized.
content: First came the rain, unforgiving in its force. Then the mud, slippery and smothering before it began to bake under the heat. The humidity only made the task of saving one of the biggest repositories of Appalachian history that much more challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: William Friedkin, Director of ‘French Connection’ and ‘Exorcist,’ Dies at 87
description: He made his name with two of the biggest box-office hits of the 1970s. But despite some later successes, he never regained his early acclaim.
content: William Friedkin, a filmmaker whose gritty, visceral style and fascination with characters on the edge helped make “The French Connection” and “The Exorcist” two of the biggest box-office hits of the 1970s, died on Monday at his home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What G.D.P.’s Cousin Can Tell Us About the Economy
description: Some economists think that an obscure metric can help predict whether a recession is on the horizon.
content: Gross domestic product is a great measure of the economy, but it would be a gross exaggeration to say it’s the only one. The Bureau of Economic Analysis also puts out gross domestic income, value added by industry and gross output by industry, to name three alternatives. The variety of indicators “puts powers in the hands of users to select the statistics that work best for their needs,” a bureau spokesman, Thomas Dail, wrote to me last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monday Briefing
description: Ukraine and Russia expand the battlefield.
content: A Ukrainian drone struck a Russian oil tanker early Saturday off the eastern coast of Russia-occupied Crimea, a day after a Ukrainian drone struck a Russian warship on the Black Sea. The attacks — the most serious strikes on the Russian Navy since last year — coincided with a new directive from Ukraine’s maritime authority warning that six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered “war risk” areas until further notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Abortion Drives Ohio Election on Amending the State Constitution
description: The election on Tuesday highlights how Republican legislators are using their power in Ohio and elsewhere.
content: For more than a century, Ohio voters have been able to amend the State Constitution with a simple majority vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Do These Shoes Make Me Look Like a Tourist?
description: A reader asks: to sneaker or not to sneaker?
content: By your shoes, they shall know you. I’m not entirely kidding. Shoes may not be the windows to the soul, but for a long time they were the source of national stereotype.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Zhu
title: What Is Your Experience With the Overdose Crisis in Baltimore?
description: People have been increasingly affected by the opioid epidemic, particularly in Baltimore City. We want to know how its residents have responded to the crisis.
content: In recent years, fatal drug overdoses have skyrocketed across the United States. Of all the major American cities where the opioid crisis has unfolded, Baltimore stands apart. It has one of the highest drug overdose rates in the country and one that disproportionately affects older Black men. Yet the issue of drug addiction — and its causes — seemingly receives little public attention compared with other issues in the city, such as gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: If Mike Pence Is a Big Hero, We’re in Big Trouble
description: Maybe Chris Christie can redeem himself, though.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll get to the latest Trump indictment in a moment, but I wanted to start by raising a subject we haven’t discussed in detail before: capital punishment. Last week, a jury sentenced Robert Bowers, who murdered 11 worshipers at Pittsburgh’s Tree of Life synagogue, to death. I sort of assume you’re against the death penalty but wanted to know your reaction to the verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Amazon to Meet Regulators as U.S. Considers Possible Antitrust Suit
description: Amazon’s meetings with the Federal Trade Commission, known as “last rites” meetings, are typically a final step before the agency votes on filing a lawsuit.
content: Amazon is scheduled to meet with members of the Federal Trade Commission next week to discuss an antitrust lawsuit that the agency may be preparing to file to challenge the power of the retailer’s sprawling business, according to a person with knowledge of the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Ivan Penn
title: Offshore Wind Runs Into Rising Costs and Delays
description: Some troubled projects are raising concerns about the role to be played by offshore wind farms in tackling climate change.
content: Vattenfall, a Swedish energy company, has for years been doing preliminary work for what would be one of the world’s largest offshore wind complexes, in the North Sea off eastern England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Alexandra Berzon
title: DeSantis Bluntly Acknowledges Trump’s 2020 Defeat: ‘Of Course He Lost’
description: “Joe Biden’s the president,” the Florida governor said in an interview with NBC News. He and other Republican presidential candidates have been testing new lines of attack against Donald Trump.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida clearly stated in a new interview that Donald J. Trump lost the 2020 election, diverging from the orthodoxy of most Republican voters, as the former president’s struggling G.O.P. rivals test out new lines of attack against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: In War on Congestion Pricing, Governor Turns to Courts and Trash Talk
description: A lawsuit that Gov. Philip Murphy of New Jersey has filed against New York’s congestion pricing plan has reignited a border war and led to charges of hypocrisy.
content: Even by New Jersey standards, a news conference Gov. Philip D. Murphy held to announce that he was suing the Biden administration over New York’s plan to charge drivers to enter Midtown Manhattan was heavy on hyperbole.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 7, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 7, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Mother, Accused of Human Trafficking While Flying With Daughter, Sues Southwest Airlines
description: An airline passenger said she and her daughter were racially profiled in 2021 while aboard a flight to Denver for a relative’s funeral.
content: Mary MacCarthy and her 10-year-old daughter, Moira, had just deplaned at Denver International Airport when two Denver police officers met them at the gate, calling them by name and notifying them that they had been reported for suspicious behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Seared Broccoli Pasta Is an ‘Absolute Slam Dunk’
description: Deeply browned florets are tossed with walnuts, mint and pecorino in this 15-minute, five-star reader favorite.
content: One of the hardest instructions for me to follow in a recipe is to “let sear,” or “allow to cook.” Letting things be is not in my nature — I’m a poker, a stirrer, a peek-er, and I like to get up close and personal with whatever I’m cooking. But restraint is exactly what’s called for in Dawn Perry’s blistered broccoli pasta with walnuts, mint and pecorino. Letting the broccoli sear without moving it allows it to char, turning the florets deeply brown and crunchy. This adds so much flavor without you having to do anything at all — except keep yourself from doing anything. It’s one of the best 15-minute pastas out there (as evidenced by its five-star rating and nearly 1,300 reader notes).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.3 Million Homes in California
description: A renovated cottage in Santa Monica, a Spanish Colonial Revival home in Santa Barbara and a three-building complex in Mendocino.
content: Rustic Canyon is a quiet Santa Monica enclave known for its locally owned restaurants and proximity to the beach. This house is across the street from Rustic Coffee, a cafe housed in a converted Airstream trailer, and down the block from Giorgio Baldi, an Italian restaurant that has been in business since 1990.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Corn Serving Platter Is the Perfect Gift for a Summer Host
description: A special feast at Kebaya, an update for the Vermont Farm Table Cookbook, and more food news.
content: As farm stands overflow with just-picked ears tasseled with silk, dedicated plates for serving corn are a joy to welcome to the summer table, like that turkey platter for you-know-when. John Derian, a designer known for his table wares and decorative accessories done with decoupage under glass, makes oval serving platters decorated with ears of yellow and red corn, 10 by 14 inches, $150. They must only be wiped clean, not immersed in water. Each is handmade; if not in stock, they require two to four weeks to deliver. Another summer option is his watermelon platter, made from glazed terra-cotta that is dishwasher-safe. Paper Trail, in Rhinebeck, N.Y., carries the corn plates, $150 each. They can also be ordered from Mr. Derian’s studio, $155 for the corn, $260 for watermelon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: The Secret Hand Behind the Women Who Stood by Cuomo? His Sister.
description: For nearly two years, Madeline Cuomo quietly worked with grass-roots activists to help smear her brother’s accusers. He was “seeing everything,” she told his defenders.
content: The menacing posts began cropping up on Twitter last September just hours after a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York sued him over sexual harassment claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Seeking Love, With Help From the City Government
description: Singles are signing up in droves for city-hosted blind-dating events, but some point to their inability to address real issues with family planning.
content: The hotel ballroom was filled with pink balloons, the sound of love songs and 100 singles gathering for a night of wine, getting acquainted and — fingers crossed — romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: A Trucking Giant Is Bankrupt, and Finger-Pointing Begins
description: Yellow, which was lent $700 million in U.S. pandemic relief, failed after being a laggard for years in a part of the industry where rivals are doing well.
content: Yellow, one of the largest trucking companies in the United States, is now in bankruptcy, three years after it got a $700 million federal loan meant to help it weather the pandemic’s upheaval. So why are rivals of the 99-year-old freight hauler doing just fine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Crypto’s Next Craze? Orbs That Scan Your Eyeballs.
description: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, has started Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project that aims to scan billions of human irises.
content: One evening last month, a crowd of cryptocurrency enthusiasts gathered at an art gallery in downtown Manhattan. They were greeted by a scene from science fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Jonathan Wolfe
title: DeSantis on Trump: ‘Of Course He Lost’
description: Tonight, check out one of our sci-fi picks for the month.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida plainly stated that Donald Trump lost the 2020 election, in an apparent change in strategy that may put him at odds with much of the Republican base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A New Generation of Oriole Magic
description: One of the youngest and cheapest rosters in Major League Baseball has powered Baltimore to the best record in the American League. The Orioles are just getting started.
content: The past and the future blended seamlessly on Saturday at Camden Yards, alternate visions of glory trimmed in orange and black. Between innings, the scoreboard showed clips from the Orioles’ last championship clincher, 40 years ago this fall. When the game resumed, the current players did a sharp imitation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Madeleine Ngo
title: Trucking Firm That Got $700 Million U.S. Bailout Declares Bankruptcy
description: A pandemic-era lifeline that the Trump administration predicted would turn a profit for the federal government failed to keep Yellow afloat.
content: Three years after receiving a $700 million pandemic-era lifeline from the federal government, the struggling freight trucking company Yellow is filing for bankruptcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Arlo Brown
title: A Pianist Adapts to Life With Parkinson’s Disease
description: Nicolas Hodges has carried on with his career as an eminent interpreter of avant-garde music. But it hasn’t been without sacrifices.
content: In the fall of 2018, the pianist Nicolas Hodges noticed his body shaking. He brought it up at a routine doctor’s appointment in Tübingen, Germany, where he lives. The doctor said it was probably stress, but recommended that he make an appointment with a neurologist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: ‘It’s Not a Sprint,’ Ukraine’s Marines Insist. ‘It’s a Marathon.’
description: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
content: They have NATO equipment and Western training. Some have English-speaking commanders, unusual in the Ukrainian military, and even an American-accented, evangelical chaplain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mayor Adams and New York’s Immigration Crisis
description: Clashing assessments of the city’s approach. Also: Donald Trump’s threat on social media; a Republican climate plan; children of elite soccer moms.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Sometimes the Love of Your Life Is an Ex
description: It’s not just Carrie and Aidan. Although most would agree that you probably shouldn’t date your ex, it can work (for some).
content: In 2013, when she was in college in Iowa, Rachel Muse Connealy had a first date with a man she was certain would be her future husband. She turned out to be right, but the road to marriage took a few turns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: The S.E.C.’s Chief Is Worried About A.I.
description: Gary Gensler, who has studied the consequences of artificial intelligence for years, said that the technology could lead to future financial crises.
content: Gary Gensler, the chairman of the S.E.C., has been studying the potential consequences of artificial intelligence for years. The recent proliferation of generative A.I. tools like ChatGPT has demonstrated that the technology is set to transform business and society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Rhiannon Giddens Is a Songwriter, Too
description: The historically minded, socially conscious musician offers bluesy, racy, playful tracks on “You’re the One,” her first full album of her own songs.
content: Rhiannon Giddens has earned a little fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: His Recycling Symbol Is Everywhere. The E.P.A. Says It Shouldn’t Be.
description: The agency wants to stop using the “chasing arrows” logo on plastics that can’t be recycled. The man who designed it more than 50 years ago agrees that the symbol has been misused.
content: Gary Anderson was a 23-year-old architecture student at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles in 1970, when he entered a design contest sponsored by a box manufacturer for a logo to promote the recycling of paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Hank the Tank, a 400-Pound Bear Behind Lake Tahoe Break-Ins, Is Captured
description: A female bear — and one of three known as Hank — was captured with her three cubs by California wildlife authorities. She was responsible for at least 21 home break-ins, officials said.
content: One of the most prolific thieves in the South Lake Tahoe, Calif., area was “safely immobilized” by tranquilizer dart and apprehended Friday morning, according to state officials: a 400-pound black bear that the public had come to know as Hank the Tank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: What to Know About Prosecutors’ Request for Protective Order in Jan. 6 Case
description: The orders, which can vary greatly in severity, generally ask that the defense use discovery evidence only to pursue actions related to the case itself and to not release it widely.
content: The first miniskirmish in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election involves a step that is taken in the early phases of many prominent criminal cases: a proposal to impose rules on how the voluminous discovery evidence in the matter should be handled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: O’Shae Sibley’s ‘Expression Was Turned Into Resistance’
description: The killing of the dancer and choreographer at a Brooklyn gas station is a stark reminder that some forms of expression are still seen as threatening.
content: That a fight over a dancing body, vibrant and free, led to a killing is still hard to believe. No — as a crowd chanted at a Brooklyn gas station on Friday night — vogueing is not a crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Even Zoom Is Making People Return to the Office
description: The tech company that helped millions of people work from home is finally tired of its employees being far away. It’s not the only one that feels that way.
content: During the early months of the pandemic, a certain company went suddenly from relative obscurity to the type of popularity that made it a noun, verb and catchphrase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Herstik and Joe Coscarelli
title: Tory Lanez Is Expected to Be Sentenced for Shooting Megan Thee Stallion
description: The Canadian rapper was found guilty in December of shooting her in both feet during an argument.
content: The Canadian rapper and singer Tory Lanez is expected to be sentenced on Tuesday for shooting Megan Thee Stallion, a fellow artist and onetime friend, in both her feet during an argument in the summer of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Israeli Missile Strike Kills 4 Near Damascus, Syria Says
description: A report in Syrian state media said the attack had come from the Golan Heights. The four killed were soldiers, it said.
content: Syrian state media reported on Monday that an Israeli missile attack targeting the vicinity of Syria’s capital, Damascus, had killed four soldiers and wounded four others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: Microgrids Are Giving Power to the People
description: Around the country, developers are building energy-resilient communities that act as their own miniature power grids.
content: As retirement neared, Eric and Camela Moulder decided to downsize from their four-bedroom home in West Grove, Pa. They had two main goals: find a place near the beach, and reduce their living expenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rumsey Taylor
title: What Distinguishes a Neil Breen Film? Neil Breen.
description: The producer, writer, director and star has made five imaginative, bewildering low-budget paranormal thrillers, spurring both ridicule and awe.
content: A mysterious orb blares across the sky and punches into the sun-baked bed of a desert landscape. From it a messianic being emerges. For the viewer it’s at this point, early in the 2009 film “I Am Here …. Now,” that the proceedings veer in one of two directions: a solemn polemic about drug use, corporate corruption and environmental exploitation; or an endearingly inept science-fiction parable, the charms of which center wholly on the middle-aged man who plays the alien being. His name is Neil Breen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why So Many Los Angeles Landmarks Are Turning 100 This Year
description: The Hollywood sign, the Memorial Coliseum and more are celebrating centennials.
content: Los Angeles is a place defined by reinvention, where history is regularly erased and replaced with something newer and shinier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Confer After Jeddah Talks
description: China underscored its desire to “actively promote” efforts to end the war in Ukraine “on any multilateral occasion.”
content: The foreign ministers of China and Russia conferred by phone on Monday, after Beijing participated in weekend talks in Saudi Arabia aimed at ending the war in Ukraine that did not include Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Cheers the Defeat of Rapinoe and the U.S. Women’s Soccer Team
description: The former president taunted a U.S. team after its defeat on the world stage.
content: When the United States lost to Sweden in the Women’s World Cup on Sunday, many American viewers saw it as a painful collapse on the grandest stage — the sort of agonizing moment that happens in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bordoff
title: Behind All the Talk, This Is What Big Oil Is Actually Doing
description: It seems increasingly evident that the oil industry is unable or unwilling to help chart a path toward a cleaner energy future.
content: If you’ve been listening to the world’s major energy companies over the past few years, you probably think the clean energy transition is well on its way. But with fossil fuel use and emissions still rising, it is not moving nearly fast enough to address the climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Massie
title: For Scotland, Leaving Will Always Be an Option
description: The settled will of the Scottish people is to remain a profoundly unsettled people.
content: In 1469, Margaret, the daughter of the king of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, married King James III of Scotland. Her father could not afford to pay the dowry in cash and so pledged his island archipelagos of Orkney and Shetland as security. Three years later the dowry was still unpaid, and James III called in the debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin, Lauren Hirsch and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Paramount Nears Announcement for Simon & Schuster Deal
description: The deal with KKR, a private equity firm, is said to be valued at roughly $1.62 billion, and could be announced as soon as Monday.
content: Paramount is preparing to announce an agreement to sell Simon & Schuster, one of the country’s top publishers, to KKR, a private-equity firm, marking the end of a yearslong attempt to sell the publishing house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Judge Throws Out Trump’s Countersuit Against E. Jean Carroll
description: The former president argued that Ms. Carroll, a former columnist, should not have said that he raped her after a jury found him liable for sexual abuse.
content: A federal judge on Monday dismissed a countersuit by former President Donald J. Trump against E. Jean Carroll, the writer whom he was found liable for sexually abusing and defaming after a civil trial in Manhattan this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: A Zoom Call, Fake Names and an A.I. Presentation Gone Awry
description: A.I. start-ups are competing fiercely with one another as a race to get ahead in the technology intensifies.
content: Arthur AI, an artificial intelligence company in New York, received a message in April last year from a start-up called OneOneThree. Yan Fung, OneOneThree’s head of technology, said he was interested in buying Arthur AI’s technology and wanted a demonstration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: August Wilson, a Theater Titan Who Spun Gold in Diners
description: The first major biography of the playwright recounts his life and boundless vision.
content: In 1986, David Mamet published his best book, a slim and semi-hardboiled treatise on theater and life titled “Writing in Restaurants.” This was decades before he became “the Kanye West of American letters,” as The Forward put it last year. Alas, the book was only vaguely about restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Can This Festival Keep a New York Sandwich Tradition Alive?
description: At Spiedie Fest in Central New York, fans explore the virtues of this grilled specialty.
content: What makes a perfect spiedie? It depends on whom you ask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find These 13 Hidden Crime and Mystery Titles?
description: Looking for literary thrills and chills this summer? As you uncover the books concealed within this text passage, a reading list appears at the bottom of the screen.
content: Looking for literary thrills and chills this summer? As you uncover the books concealed within this text passage, a reading list appears at the bottom of the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Philippine Coast Guard Meets Chinese Blockade
description: Video shows the Chinese Coast Guard firing a water cannon at a Philippine vessel and blocking it from executing a resupply mission.
content: Video shows the Chinese Coast Guard firing a water cannon at a Philippine vessel and blocking it from executing a resupply mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Residents Rush to Help After Deadly Train Derailment in Pakistan
description: Rescue teams and army personnel combed through the wreckage in Nawabsha, Pakistan, with the help of people from nearby villages.
content: Rescue teams and army personnel combed through the wreckage in Nawabsha, Pakistan, with the help of people from nearby villages.
source.name: The New York Times
